+coldblooded kidder really u didn't know that?? did u read the 
silmarillion? If u did then u should know that, but if not then its 
understandable...Melkor was renamed Morgoth by Feanor (An Elf) after he 
stole the Silmarils (they were the gems crafted by Feanor from some essence 
of the Two Trees of Valinor; Laurelin and Telperion, before the First Age. 
They were among the most prized of all the wonders crafted by the elves and 
were coveted by many) and murdered his Father Finwe, deceiving the Ainur in 
the process and fleeing to Middle Earth to rebuild his dark forces...Also 
if you've seen LOTR then u know Sauron...Melkor/Morgoth is basically 
Sauron's Boss, Sauron was basically his second in command--actually sharing 
that position with another Balrog...which was the monster that Gandalf 
fights the first and second movie. After the third war with Morgoth who was 
defeated by the Valar(basically like gods who rule the world--to put it 
simply although its a lot more complicated than that) Sauron basically 
takes over the remainder of his forces and thats basically when he starts 
rising in power and the LOTR stories sort of evolve from. Sorry for the 
history lesson, it's just a really complicated to explain to someone who 
doesn't have any context although I doubt this cleared much up, in fact 
probably confused the hell out of u if you don't know the story
+james leatherman I didn't know that. Thank you

 That ruined it for me. The armies were obviously computer generated but it

But it is different, since the rights of The Lord of the Rings and The 
Hobbit, sold them before they left the movies, and Christopher Tolkien 
(heir of JRR Tolkien, rights holder) said: "They destroyed the book, making 
an action movie for kids between 15 and 25 years. "Besides Peter Jackson 
himself acknowledged in the past Comic-Con did not believe there is any 
adaptation of The Silmarillion in quite some time. "I believe that if you 
leave a film is going to be in a long time. Sorry for my Inglés, I use 
google translator.

+Lootcatcher No they didn't. Tolkein sold the rights before he died to Saul 
Zaentz (aka Middle-Earth Enterprises). Technically, the Tolkein estate (by 
legal tender) has 0 licencing rights to LOTR and Hobbit but still deserve 
royalties. All other books are a different story, which many actually have 
had work done by Christopher Tolkein to finish them off.

AGORA EM FILME!!!
O Silmarillion compreende cinco partes.
A primeira parte, "Ainulindalë (A Música dos Ainur)", conta da criação de 
Eä, o "mundo que é". "Valaquenta (O Relato dos Valar)", a segunda parte, dá 
a descrição dos Valar e Maiar, os poderes sobrenaturais de Eä.
A próxima seção, Quenta Silmarillion (A História das Silmarils), que forma 
a maior parte do livro, narra a história dos eventos antes e durante a 
Primeira Era, incluindo as guerras sobre as Silmarils (de onde vem o nome 
do livro). A quarta parte, Akallabêth, relata a história da Queda de 
Númenor e seu povo, que tem seu lugar na Segunda Era. A parte final, "Dos 
Anéis de Poder e a Terceira Era", é um breve relato das circunstâncias que 
levaram aos eventos narrados em O Senhor dos Anéis.
As cinco partes eram, inicialmente, trabalhos separados, mas foi um desejo 
que Tolkien expressou, já idoso, de que eles fossem publicados juntos. 
Devido à morte de J. R. R. Tolkien antes de terminar de revisar as várias 
lendas que criou, Christopher, seu filho, juntou o antigo material escrito 
de seu pai para preencher o livro. Em alguns casos, isso significa que ele 
teve de criar material completamente novo para preencher as lacunas e 
incoerências na narrativa.
A série History of Middle-earth forma doze volumes num raio-x do processo 
que levou ao Senhor dos Anéis e ao Silmarillion através do olhar inicial de 
J.R.R. Tolkien e de comentários de seu filho Christopher.
O Silmarillion, como outros trabalhos de Tolkien sobre a Terra-Média, toma 
lugar em algum espaço de tempo na história da Terra (Arda). O Silmarillion 
era para ser uma tradução do terceiro volume dos livros de Bilbo, 
"Traduções do Élfico", o qual ele escreveu em Valfenda/Rivendell/Imladris.
Dentre os mais notáveis capítulos, estão:
"A Música dos Ainur (Ainulindalë)";
"De Beren e Lúthien";
"De Túrin Turambar" (descrito também nos livros Contos Inacabados e Os 
Filhos de Húrin);
"De Tuor e da queda de Gondolin";
"De Eärendil e da Guerra da Ira".﻿
